titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.35 (23 Aug-30 Aug 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 35. Mercurius Publicus, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence: WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 23. to Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 30. 1660.
We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p: HIS Excellency the Lord General Monck being Lord Lievtenant of his own Native County of Devon, hath nominated and cho≈øen divers Noble Gentlemen of known Honour and Loyalty to His Maje≈øty, to be Deputy Leivtenants of that County. Their Commi≈øons are all Sealed, who need no other Commendation but to tell this newes, viz.

list.item: Sir John Chiche≈øter of Hull Knight.

div.p: We have formerly acquainted you how the re≈øpectiv ‚Ä¢ Regiments of the Army in England have been di≈øpo≈øed‚ñ™ and now we ≈øhall tell you in what hands His Maje≈øty hath entru≈øted the Garri≈øon of Dunkirk, wherein are four good Regiments, three of Foot, and one of Hor≈øe, viz.

list.item: Edward Harley, Col. and Captain, Governour of Dunkirk.
William Fleetwood Lieut. Col. and Capt.
Henry Gargran Q. M. and Mar≈øhal Gen.
Thomas Heynes Lieut. Col. and Capt.
Geo. Clinton alias Fiennes Maj. and Cap.
Maurice Kingwel Lieut. Col. and Capt.
Fra. Pockley Phy≈øitian to the Garri≈øon.

_____
Flower Cap¬∑ Lt. to Col. Ed. Harley.

div.p: On Thur≈øday the 23 of this In≈øtant Augu≈øt, Frederick Van Alefeldt, Amba≈ø≈øadour Extraordinary from His Maje≈øty of Danemarke, came to London, with a very noble retinue; his Servants in very rich Liveries: Sir Charles Cottrel His Maje≈øties Ma≈øter of the Ceremonies, with ≈øeveral Coaches of the chief Nobility, went to meet him, and conducted him to Sir Abraham William's Hou≈øe, at the Palace in We≈øtmin≈øter.

You have heard heretofore how Commi≈ø≈øions under the Great Seal were i≈ø≈øued forth, impowring ≈øeveral Officers of the Army to admini≈øter the Oathes of Supremacy and Allegiance to the re≈øpective Officers and Souldiers of each Regiment: In performance of which duty the ≈øaid Officers have been very diligent, particularly in His Excellency the Lord Generals Regiment of Hor≈øe, where Major Iohn≈øon (who ≈øo prudently prevented the betraying of Berwick to Lambert) and Cap. Symnel ≈øhewed now as much readine≈øs, as they had formerly Valour, in advancing with Cap. Wilmot ≈øo daringly to Morpeth in Northumberland, with four Troops. The≈øe two riding from Troop to Troop, found all the Officers and Souldiery as willing to take the Oathes as they to admini≈øter, one only Trooper in the whole Regiment di≈ø≈øenting.

The like care was u≈øed in admini≈øtring the ≈øaid Oathes to His Excellencies Regiment of Foot, where al≈øo but one only Souldier di≈ø≈øented. In Col. Hubblethorn's Regiment of Foot only one di≈ø≈øented. In Col. Litcot's but one only. In Col. Read's but one; and in Sir Ralph Knight's Regiment of Hor≈øe but one; where we cannot but take notice of the equal care of all the≈øe faithful Officers, that in each Regiment there ≈øhould be but one di≈ø≈øenting; and that the prudence of them all hath been ≈øo great, in entertaining Souldiers in ≈øuch di≈øtracted times, where there is but one in each Regiment, and not one Officer in any. And you cannot but ob≈øerve how fair and freely tho≈øe Officers have dealt, that ≈øuch as had any the lea≈øt ≈øcruple again≈øt tho≈øe mo≈øt ju≈øt and legal Oathes, had yet liberty (without any force or threats) to expre≈øs their di≈ø≈øents, and yet after all this fifting and winnowing, there was not
≈øeven men in ≈øix Regiments but did mo≈øt cheerfully take the ≈øaid Oaths, and tho≈øe ≈øix, common Souldiers (for Officers none) who were Di≈ø≈øenters, were found upon examination to be Forraigners, and Roman Catholiques.

Colonel Charls Fairfax hath likewi≈øe returned an account of the readine≈øs of all his Officers and Souldiers in taking the ≈øaid Oaths: The manner of the Return (which is the Form u≈øed in ≈øuch ca≈øes) was thus, viz.

body.p: Commi≈øsio in Cancellaria pro Sacramentis prae≈øtandis Officiariis & militibus ≈øub Regimine Caroli Fairfax Colonelll.
body.closer: Retorn. ≈øine dilatione. Sealed and Endor≈øed C. FAIRFAX. Iohn Rogers. Bailly. For His Maje≈øties Service.

div.p: But ≈øince we are upon an Accompt of admini≈øtring the Oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance, we mu≈øt not conceal a particular ≈øent us from Cooper in Scotland Augu≈øt 14. where the ≈øaid Oaths were freely taken by the four Troops of the Lord Vi≈øcount Falkland's Regiment in Falkland, and not the lea≈øt que≈øtion or ≈øcruple made by any, except only one in Major Morgan's Troop, who being ab≈øent when the re≈øt took tho≈øe Oaths, upon his return was informed by his fellow-Souldiers that they had all taken the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and that he was called for. Whereupon he ≈øaid, I have an hair in my throat, that I cannot ≈øwallow, but in≈øtantly fell ≈øtarke mad, and ran roaring and crying up and down; four men could ≈øcarce rule him; in which ≈øad condition he continued three days, and then died mo≈øt mi≈øerably. A ≈øufficient caveat for all who heretofore ≈øo ea≈øily ≈øwallowed ≈øo many new oaths, to be now puni≈øhed by ≈øcrupling at an hair, though in their mo≈øt ju≈øt and undoubted Allegiance.

div.head: Saturday, Aug. 25.
div.p: His Excellency to ea≈øe the burthen and charge of the Nation, this day did di≈øpatch expre≈øs Orders to the ≈øeveral Regiments of the Army, to take in no more Officers or Souldiers in place of any vacant by death or otherwi≈øe.

And now (after ≈øo many conferences and debates by the Lords and Commons in Parliament) it hath plea≈øed God that the Act of Indempnity which His Maje≈øty hath ≈øo often pre≈øs'd and call'd for, is ≈øo near perfection, that it's verily beleiv'd 'twill ≈øuddenly be publi≈øhed to the world in Print.

In pur≈øuance whereof that worthy and faithfull Sir John Robin≈øon, Knight and Barronet, His Maje≈øties Leivtenant of the Tower of London, received into his cu≈øtody ≈øeven of tho≈øe who ≈øate as Judges on the life of His late Maje≈øty, viz. Colonell Waite, Colonell Temple, Colonell Robert Lilburn, _____ Smith of Leice≈øter≈øheir, E≈øq Colonell Henry Martin, _____ Carey, E≈øq Colonell Downes.

The≈øe ≈øeven were committed this evening to the Tower, (where more of the ≈øame Order are expected on Monday next) what their fate hereafter will be we cannot ≈øufficiently affirm, but are certain that at pre≈øent they are in nobler cu≈øtody then His Maje≈øties be≈øt Subjects when in the ≈øame place.

div.head: Lisbone, Aug. 10. S. N.
div.p: After the three dayes rejoycings, of which formerly I gave you an account; the King gave order for Touros Reales, in Engli≈øh, the Royal Bull baiting to be performed by the principal of the Nobility. The Conde, the Torre is nominated for the fir≈øt of tho≈øe who are to ride. This ≈øport is to continue nine dayes with all the ≈øolemn pomp po≈ø≈øible. The Ma≈øt in the middle of the Pallace-yard, where this Fe≈øtival is to be celebrated, is to bear the Flag of England, to put all ≈øpectators in mind that all this is performed in token of joy for his Maje≈øty of England his Re≈øtoration to his Hereditary right, where you may ≈øee how this people who were ≈øo exact in their mourning for the execrable murther of the Father, do expre≈øs their joy for the good fortune of his Son. The Engli≈øh Factors here are preparing ≈øomthing to expre≈øs likewi≈øe their joy, but do expect the arrival of their Con≈øull before they perform it.

div.head: A Relation of the manner of the Reception of the King and Queen of France into Paris, on the 16th of Augu≈øt, S. N.
div.p: The Militia's ordered to give their attendance at the Reception of their Maje≈øties of France, being drawn upon the 13 currant in a great Plain, not far from the Ca≈øtle of Vincennes. The King went thither to take a view of all the ≈øeveral Batalions, which were ranged in no le≈øs good order by the Pre≈øident of Guenegaud their Commander in chief, than they appeared richly accou≈øtred, as well as tho≈øe who were commanded by other Officers; each one ≈øtriving to out do the other, in appearing with as much gallantry as po≈ø≈øible, to ≈øhow them≈øelves to ≈øo great a Monarch, and to be ≈øeen by that Illu≈øtrious and Accompli≈øhed Prince≈øs, who did them the honor to come and to take a view of them. Their Maje≈øties being accompanied by all the Lords and Ladies of the Court in decent manner, a company of Mu≈øquetiers armed and Light-hor≈øemen went before, and brought up the Rear of them in ≈øuch an orderly method, that the whole Body did extraordinarily plea≈øe the people which came from the City to behold it. The 25. being St. Louys day, the Queen Mother, attended by the Prince of Conde, the Duke of Enguyen, the Prince of Conty, many Ladies of great quality, and mo≈øt part of the Prelates who made up the A≈ø≈øembly of the Clergy, went to the Church of the Je≈øuites in St. Anthonie's ≈øtreet, to hear a Panegyrick touching the King, held there by the Abbot of Tonnere with much Eloquence and a general Applau≈øe.

The 26th. day of Augoe≈øt being appointed for the Reception of their Maje≈øties, about ≈øeven a Clock in the morning the King came on Hor≈øeback from the Ca≈øtle of Vincennes, to a mo≈øt ≈øtately Throne rai≈øed at the end of the Suburbs of St. Anthony, whither the Queen al≈øo pre≈øently after came in a ≈øumptuous Chariot, Their Maje≈øties ≈øeated them≈øelves in a Chair of State under a rich Canopy with gold Fringes, as were the re≈øt of the Ornaments of this Theater. On his Maje≈øties right hand, there ≈øtood the Chancellor of France, the Duke of Bovillon High Chamberlain behind him, next to whom the Count of Treme Captain of the Guardes, and by
him, next to whom the Count of Treme, Captain of the Guards, and by him the Duke of Crequi, Chief Gentleman of the Chamber took their places; behinde the Queen ≈øtood the Dutche≈øs of Navailles, her Maje≈øties chief Lady of Hono ‚Ä¢ , and the Counte≈øs of Bethune, the Lady of her Attire: On the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ were placed Madamoi≈øelle, and the re≈øt of the daughters of Orleans, Al ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øon a ‚Ä¢
Valois, the Prince≈øs of Co ‚Ä¢ de, and all the other Prince≈ø≈øs and Ladies. Mon≈øieur was next to the King, with the Prince o ‚Ä¢
Conde, the Duke of Enguyen, and the Prince of Conti and other per≈øons of quality of the Court, placed upon the ≈øeveral degrees of the Royal Throne, at the end whereof were his Maje≈øties Guards, with a hundred Swi≈ø≈øes all along the Rails, and without all the Citizens in their Arms, ≈øtanding filewi≈øe to this very Town. Pre≈øently after came the ≈øeveral Pari≈øhioners, who when they had in pa≈ø≈øing by ≈øaluted their Maje≈øties, were followed by the Univer≈øity, the Rector whereof complemented their Maje≈øties; after them came the ≈øeveral Companies of the City, who delivered their ≈øen≈øe by the Provo≈øt of Marcants; tho≈øe of the Courts of Ju≈øtice, in who≈øe behalf the Lieutenant of civil affairs made a Speech, and then came the Souveraen Companies, to wit, tho≈øe of the Court of Moneys, of the Court of Aydes, of the Chamber of Accounts and the Parliament, the chief whereof being received at the foot of the Throne by the Seurs of Rodes and Saintot, Great Ma≈øter, and Ma≈øter of the Geremonies, and pre≈øented by the Seur of Ple≈ø≈øes, Guenegaud, Secretary of State, delivered likewi≈øe their Complements. Which done, their Maje≈øties being retired through a Gallery, into a hou≈øe that was prepared near the Throne, the Company of the Provo≈øt of the I≈øle began their march, followed by three≈øcore and twelve Mu≈øes of his Eminencies, covered with very rich coverings, with their Querries, Officers, Gentlemen and Guards, all in a very hand≈øom and orderly equipage, together with ninety mules of his Maje≈øties, and the Officers of the great and little Stables. Next to them went the Secretaries of the King, and the Ma≈øters of Reque≈øts,
led on by the U≈øhers of the Chain, the Controllers-General, and the great Auditors of the Chancery, the four U≈øhers with their ≈øilver-gilt M ‚Ä¢ ces, who went before a white Mare, (which carried a ≈ømall box of ≈øilver-gilt, with the ≈øeals of France in it on her back, richly dre≈ø≈øed and clothed with a cloth of Velvet of violet colour, imbroidered with flowers de Luces of Gold, the four corners whereof were bore up by the four Chaufe cires
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oot. Th ‚Ä¢ n came the Chancellor of France in his robe and ca≈ø≈øock of cloth of gold, mounted on a brave hor≈øe clothed with the ≈øame ≈øtaff, having on each ≈øide of him his Pages, and a great number of Footmen in violet-coloured L ‚Ä¢ very of Velvet laced with gold lace, after whom fol ‚Ä¢ owed ≈øome ‚Ä¢ f his Dome≈øticks, the Kings Mu≈øquetiers, the Lighthor≈øemen, the Exempts and Guards of the Provo≈øt‚ñ™ del' Ho≈øtel, the Marque≈øs of Souches leading them up, and a ‚Ä¢ reat number of Lords excellently well mounted: the Marque≈øs of Vardes brought up the hundred Sui≈ø≈øes, then came the Heralds at Arms, the great Ma≈øter of the Artillery, ≈øeveral Mar≈øhals of France ‚ñ™ all in a ≈øplendid equipage, and next the C ‚Ä¢ unt of Harcourt M ‚Ä¢ ≈øter of the hor≈øe, carrying the Royal Sword before his Maje≈øty, who now ≈øeemed more gallant and lovelier on this occa≈øion, then heretofore in all his famous Conque≈øts; he had on his ≈øide ≈øix Gentlemen of the Hor≈øe, at his right hand the Duke of Bovillon his High Chamberlain, after came the Duke of Tremes, Captain of the Guards, the Duke of Crequi, chief Gentleman of his C ‚Ä¢ amber, and the Sieur of Bellingen, chief Ma≈øter of the little tables. Next to them went Mon≈øieur alone, who by his good meen and rich equipage, was ea≈øily known; after him came the Prince of Conde, the Prince of Conty, and the Duke of Enguien, all excellently well accoutred; and after them the C ‚Ä¢ unt of Soi≈ø≈øons, with a great many other Lords; the Hand of the Gentlemen-Pen≈øioners, and the Pages of the Queens Chamber, who went immediately before the Prince≈øs ≈øeated in a Chariot of Triumph, attended on one ≈øide by the Duke of Gui≈øe, with the other Princes of the hou≈øe of Lorrain, and on the other by the Count of Fuen≈øeldagne
wherein was Madamoi≈øelle and the three Prince≈ø≈øes her Si≈øters; next, the ≈øecond Coach, with other Ladies: after them came the Kings Life-Guard and Hor≈øemen, and la≈øt of all the Officers of the Hawks, who ended this long and numerous Cavalcade.

Their Maje≈øties being arived at the Gate of St. Anthony, which was ≈øtately adorned, and where the ≈øeveral Companies of the Town ≈øtaid for them, the Provo≈øt of the Merchants pre≈øented them with two Canopies of Cloth of Gold; That of the King, was ≈øupported by the Sieurs Le Vieux and Bodequ ‚Ä¢ n Sheriffs, with the two fir≈øt Guards of the Company of Drapery; that of the Queens was carried by the Sieurs Prevo≈øt and du Jour, Sheriffs, with two other Guards of the ≈øame company. Thence they proceeded on their march through the ≈øtreet of St. Anthony, where the Queen-Mother had taken up her place at that fair Hou≈øe of Madam de Beauvais, where there was likewi≈øe the Queen of England, with the Prince≈øs her Daughter, his Eminency, the Prince≈øs Palatine, and a number of other Ladies of great quality: Then they marched through the ≈øtreet of Ti≈ø≈øerandery, L'Ho≈øtel de Ville, Le Pont No≈øtredame, Le Marche Neuf, La Place Dauphine and Pont Neuf, until they came to the Louvre. There being in all the≈øe pa ‚Ä¢ ts mo≈øt ≈øumptuous Arches of triumph erected, and filled with people, who by their redoubled acclamations, ≈øhewed their joyfulne≈øs to behold ≈øo excellent and perfect a Prince≈øs.

Their Maje≈øties went ye≈øterday to No≈øtredame, where they found a≈ø≈øembled the Chancellor of France, the Parliament, the Chamber of Accounts, and the Court of Aydes, with the Companies of the City, and after they were received and complemented there by the Dean of the Church, they heard the Te Deum ≈øung with a particular ≈øolemnity, befitting the pre≈øence of the≈øe two great Objects of our publick joy. There were likewi≈øe pre≈øent Mon≈øieur, the Prince of Conde, the Duke of Enguien, and the Prince of Conty, Mademoi≈øelle, the Prince≈øs of Conde, and all the other Lords and Ladies of the Court; the Clergy, the Popes Nuntio, the Count of
Fuen≈øeldagne, the Amba≈ø≈øadors of Venice and Savoy, and ≈øo many other per≈øons of quality: So that there was never a more numerous and more ≈øplendid A≈ø≈øembly ≈øeen here before.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books newly Printed nd Publi≈øhed.
div.p: ‚òû Veritus Inconcu≈ø≈øa, or a mo≈øt certain Truth a≈øcertained, That King Charls the Fir≈øt was no man of B ‚Ä¢ ood, but a Martyr for his people. By Fabian Phillips E≈øq Sold by Williom Pl ‚Ä¢ ce at Grays-Inn Gate.
The Bowels of Tender Mercy Sealed in the Everla≈øting Covenant; as al≈øo the Trea≈øures of Grace, &c. By Mr. Obadiah Sedgwick.

The r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ king of the Bi ‚Ä¢ ter Cup; or the harde≈øt Le≈ø≈øon in Chri≈øts School, learned and taught by him≈øelf, Pa≈ø≈øive Obedience, by John Brin≈øley, Mini≈øter of the G ‚Ä¢ ≈øpel at Great Yarmouth.
Both ≈øold by Jo≈øeph Cranford at the Ca≈øtle and Lion in St. Pauls Churchyard.

The Beatitudes: Or a Di≈øcour≈øe upon part of Chri≈øts famous Sermon on the Mount. By Thomas Wat≈øon, Mini≈øter of the Word at Stephens Walhrook in the City of London. Printed for Ralph Smith at the Bible in Cornhill, near the Royal Exchange, 1660.
Manaductio, or a Leading of Children by the hand through the principles of Grammar. By James Shirley.
An Epi≈øtle written and pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty, by A ‚Ä¢ i≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an ‚Ä¢ who yet live ‚Ä¢ h. Both ≈øold by Richard Lownds at the White Lion in St. Pauls Churchyard.

div.head: An Adverti≈øement.
div.p: GEntlemen, You are de≈øired to take notice, That Mr. Th ‚Ä¢ ophilus Buckworth, who for ≈øome years pa≈øt permitted, and gave directions to his Brother Mr. Edmond Buckworth, to make and expo≈øe to ≈øale, for the publick good, tho≈øe ≈øo famous Lozanges or Pectorals, approved for the cure of Con≈øumptions, Coughs, Catarrhs, A≈øthma's, Hoar≈øne≈øs, Strongne≈øs of Breath, Colds in general, Di≈øea≈øes incident to the Lungs, and a ≈øoveraign Antidote again≈øt the Plague, and all other contagious Di≈øea≈øes, and ob≈øtructions of the Stomach, doth now him≈øelf (being the Author and fir≈øt compounder of them) make them at his Hou≈øe on Mile-end Green. And for more convenience of the people, con≈øtantly leaveth them ≈øealed up with his Coat of Arms on the papers, with Mr. Rich. Lowndes (as formerly) at the ≈øign of the White Lion near the little North door of Pauls Church, Mr. Henry Seilt over again≈øt Dun≈øtans Church in Fleet≈øtreet, Mr. William Milward at We≈øtmin≈øter Hall-Gate, Mr. John Place at Furnivals-Inn Gate in Holborn, and Mr. Robert Horn at the Turks-head near the entrance of the Royal Exchange, Book≈øellers, and no others.
This is publi≈øhed to prevent the de≈øigns of divers Pretenders, who counterfeit the ≈øaid Lozenges to the di≈øparagement of the ≈øaid Gentleman, and great abu≈øe of the People.

THat then there came to the Hou≈øe of Mr. William Grove of Grove, in the Pari≈øh of Wanting, in the County of Berks, ≈øeven hor≈ømen (pretending them ‚Ä¢ elves to be Soldiers) with Ho ‚Ä¢ ≈øters and Pi≈øtols mo≈øt of them being in Grey Sui ‚Ä¢ s and Coats, two of them in ≈øadder colored coates then the other, one of which had no boots, but only white boot ho≈øe tops, one of their Hor≈øes being an Iron Grey, one other having a br ‚Ä¢ wn bay Mare, but cut-maned and ri ‚Ä¢ ged, and the others hor≈øes being bay, who pretending to ≈øearch the hou≈øe for Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ et Joyce, and accu≈øing Mr. Grove of High Tre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , by vertue of an Order (as they pretended from the Lord General robbed the Hou≈øe, and took away three≈øcore and ten pounds in mony, ≈øome ‚Ä¢ ieces of Gol ‚Ä¢ , and a Wedding Ring, and afterwards took the ≈øaid Mr. Grove and his Son, pretending they mu≈øt have them to London, and carried them towards Oxford, into a place called Bagly wood, and having them there di≈ømounted them, and took from them a Grey Mare, of about twelve pounds price, being cut maned, having one Jaw thicker, and hanging down ≈øomwhat lower then the other, about Fourteen hand and a hall high, and one I ‚Ä¢ on grey g ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ Colt, about three years old and a quarter, of about ‚Ä¢ en pound price, being a very hand≈øome Colt, with Bridles and Saddles, and about twenty ≈øhillings in mony, and bou ‚Ä¢ d them and left them in the wood I any one ≈øhall ≈øeize and ≈øecure any of the ≈øaid per≈øons, or the Mare and Colt ≈øo taken away, let them give o ‚Ä¢ ≈øend notice to the ≈øaid Mr Grove afore≈øaid, or to John Coombes at the Windmill in St. Pauls-Church-yard, and t ‚Ä¢ ey ≈øhall be well rewarded.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to confer the honor of Knighthood on Lieu. colonel John Jack≈øon of Harraton in the County of Durham, as a pre≈øent mark of his Royal favor for his loyal ≈øervices and ≈øufferings in the Wars.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p: Col. Francis Windham (who ≈øo nobly held out Dunster-ca≈øtle for his Maje≈øty) being lately cho≈øen Burge≈øs for Milburn Port in the county of Somer≈øet, now ≈øits in the Hou≈øe of Commons; and among all tho≈øe hundreds of Members that fit there, not any hath ≈øerved his Maje≈øty with more fidelity and ≈øucce≈øs than that Gentleman, e≈øpecially at ≈øuch times when others for≈øook him, and his Maje≈øty had mo≈øt need of friends, which we need not tell you was in his Maje≈øties great and wonderful e≈øcape after the battel at Worce≈øter.

And ≈øince we mention e≈øcapes, we cannot forget the Noble and valiant Lord Inchequin, who on Friday la≈øt the 24. in≈øtant, came to London to fini≈øh his redemption from the Turki≈øh ≈ølavery, where his Son is left as Pledge till his Ran≈øom be accompli≈øh'd.

His Excellency the Duke of Albemarle hath reinforc'd his late Order to the Commi≈ø≈øary-general of the Mu≈øters and his Deputies, to take care that no Officers or Soldiers be mu≈øtered in any dead place, or any other way vacant.

div.head: Edenbrough Augu≈øt 21.
div.p:
M ‚Ä¢ jor G ‚Ä¢ neral Morgan (in pur≈øuance of his Excellencies Orders) with eight Companies of his Regiment, is removed from Haly-Rood hou≈øe in Edenbrough (a place famous for the King of Scotlands wonted M ‚Ä¢ n≈øion) to Leith Cittadel: Lieut. Col. Jo≈øeph W ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tar, his Lieut. Col. Commands Sterling Ca≈øtle with two Companies of the Major Generals Regiment. Orders are ≈øent to ≈øeven Companies of Col. Daniels Regiment to march to A ‚Ä¢ re in place of Col. Rob≈øons. Two Companies of Col. Daniels Regiment, and two of Col. Mau's are ≈øent to St. John≈øtons, Commanded by Lieut. Col. Richard≈øon. And by this time I pre≈øume you de≈øire to know how many Garri≈øons and ≈øtrong Holds of Scotland are re≈øerved in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Engli≈øh: which are,
The Cittadel of Leith.
The Cittadel of St. John≈øtons.
The Cittadel of Ayre.
The Cittadel of Innerne≈øs.
Sterling Ca≈øtle.
Dunbarton Ca≈øtle.
Dun≈øtafnal Ca≈øtle, and
Dower Ca≈øtle.

The Earl of Glencarne now Lord Chancellor of Scotland is expected here at Ediuburgh to morrow, and is to be attended hither very honorably, many per≈øons of quality citizens and others to a very great number being already gone to meet him.
To this news from Edinburgh we may adde, that General Middleton is made his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioner.

list.item: Earl of Lauderdale, Principal Secretary of State.
Sir John Fietcher, his Maje≈øties Advocate.
Mr. Gilbert Stuart, Lion King at Arms.

div.p:
Since tho≈øe excepted out of the Act of Oblivion, who were committed to the Tower on ≈øaturday la≈øt, having ≈øate as Judges on his late Maje≈øty, the≈øe following (who al≈øo were ≈øuch Judges) are ≈øent to the ≈øame place, viz.
Sir Hardre≈øs Waller
Sir James Temple
Col. Scroope
Col. George Fleetwood
Alderman Tichburn
Mr. Garland
Mr. Heveningham
Col. Owen Row
Col. Harvey
Col. Potter.
Mr. Mayne
Mr. Millington.
His Maje≈øty this day Aug. 29. went to the Parliament, and gave his Royal A≈ø≈øent to the≈øe five Acts, viz.

list.item: 1. An Act for confirmation of Judicial proceedings.
2. An Act for re≈øtraining the taking of exce≈ø≈øive U≈øury.
3. An Act for a perpetual Anniver≈øary Thank≈øgiving on the 29 of May (the day of his Maje≈øties Nativity and Re≈øtauration.)
4. An Act of Free and General Pardon, Indempnity and Oblivion.
5. An Act for a ≈øpeedy provi≈øion of Money to pay off and disband all the Forces of the Kingdome both by Sea and Land, (commonly called, The Act for Poll-money.)

div.p: His Maje≈øty in memory of that great ≈øervice done to the Crown in the days of his Royal Father, as well as ≈øince his Maje≈øty began his Reign by that wi≈øe and mo≈øt Honourable Per≈øonage Earl of Southampton, hath made his Lord≈øhip Lord High Trea≈øurer of England.
